page.title: 19Rawmarsh dialect
page.content: The Rawmarsh area is rich in dialect some of which may be regarded as Yorkshire dialect but much of which is very local - while in common use in Rawmarsh it may not be used in other parts of Rotherham. This reflects the very localised sense of identity which leads some people to say, for example, "I come from Sandhill, not Rawmarsh". Some dialect has its origins in the mining tradition of the area but much of it pre-dates this. The influ- ence of television does not appear to have significantly diminished the use of dialect which is still strong among schoolchildren. As well as 'pure' dialect there are also pronunciations like 'papper' (paper) and 'skoyal' (school) which should be regarded more as dialect than as mispronunciations.
